explanation: The report is correct. If url == "" then url is a pointer to a 1-byte array containing just '\0'; &url[1] is a pointer one past the array. While forming a one-past-the-end pointer is allowed, any attempt to read via that pointer is undefined. The code passes &url[1] to functions that read the pointed-to bytes (strstr, strrchr, strcmp via subsequent reads, and open which will read a C string), and also directly evaluates url[1] in ('/' != url[1]). All of those will attempt to access memory beyond the object when url is empty, so they can perform out‑of‑bounds accesses and thus violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. A safe fix is to ensure the string has at least two characters (e.g. check url[0] == '/' and url[1] != '\0') before using &url[1], or otherwise guard those calls.
